{{Climbing sidebar |image=Bild auf dem Gedenkstein fuer Guellich (retuschiert).jpg |caption=[[Wolfgang Gullich]] climbing in [[Frankenjura]] ([[Germany|DEU]]). }} In [[free climbing]], a '''first ascent''' ('''FA'''), or '''first free ascent''' ('''FFA''') is the first successful, documented climb of a [[Climbing route|route]] or [[boulder]] performed without using equipment such as [[Anchor (climbing)|anchors]], [[quickdraw]]s or [[Dynamic rope|ropes]] for aiding progression or resting. In this article, notable first free ascents of hard routes and boulders are listed. [[Grade (climbing)|Ratings]] on the hardest climbs tend to be speculative, until other climbers have had a chance to complete the routes and a consensus can be reached on the precise [[Grade (climbing)|grade]]. This becomes increasingly difficult as the grade increases, because fewer climbers are capable of repeating the route and passing judgment on its grade. [[File:Adam Ondra climbing Silence, 9c by PAVEL BLAZEK 1-cropped.jpg|thumb|left|250 px|[[Adam Ondra]] climbing [[#Redpointed|''Silence'']], {{Climbing grade|9c}}, in 2017]] == Overview == As of November 2017: * The hardest ascended route ([[#Redpointed|''Silence'']]) has a proposed grade of {{climbing grade|9c}}. It was first ascended by [[Adam Ondra]] in 2017 and no one else has yet repeated it. * The hardest route ever ascended by a woman is [[#PlantaShiva|''La Planta de Shiva'']], graded {{climbing grade|9b}}. [[Angela Eiter]] claimed its first female ascent in 2017 and no other woman has yet repeated it. * The hardest ascended [[Bouldering|boulder problem]] ([[#Boulder problems|''Burden of dreams'']]) has a proposed grade of {{Boulder grade|9A}}. It was first ascended by [[Nalle Hukkataival]] in 2016 and no one else has yet repeated it. * The hardest routes ever successfully climbed [[on-sight]] are graded {{Climbing grade|9a}}. The first [[on-sight]] ascent of a {{Climbing grade|9a}} route ([[#Onsighted|''Estado Critico'']]) was claimed by [[Alex Megos]] in March 2013. The second ([[#Onsighted|''Cabane au Canada'']]) by Adam Ondra in July 2013. No one else has yet onsighted this grade. == Single-[[pitch (climbing)|pitch]] routes == === [[Redpoint (climbing)|Redpointed by men]] === {{climbing grade|9c}} (unconfirmed): :* [[Silence (climb)|''Silence'']] (formerly known as ''Project Hard''){{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BYxqK3NFG6n/?hl=en&taken-by=adam.ondra|title=Silence 9c, Flatanger, Norway|publisher=Instagram|author=Adam Ondra}} - [[Flatanger]] ([[Norway|NOR]]) - September 3, 2017 - First ascent by [[Adam Ondra]], who described it as "much harder than anything else" he had previously done, and cautiously suggested the 9c rating. The route is about 45 m long. The first 20 m are about {{climbing grade|8B}}, followed by three distinct boulder problems: an extremely hard 8C, a "burly 4-move" 8B and a 7C+ with slippery feet. The first one was described by Ondra as the hardest {{Boulder grade|8C}} he ever climbed. It consists of 10 incredibly hard and unusual moves, including single-[[Glossary of climbing terms#finger_jam|finger locks]], climbing upside down and a variation of a [[Glossary of climbing terms#figure four|figure four]] move. {{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/interviews/adam-ondra-climbs-worlds-first-9c-at-flatanger-in-norway.html|title=Interview: Adam Ondra climbs world's first 9c at Flatanger in Norway|editor=planetmountain.com|date=September 4, 2017|access-date=September 4, 2017}} {{web cite|url=https://www.ukclimbing.com/news/item/71256/adam_ondra_climbs_worlds_first_9c_-_project_hard|title=Adam Ondra climbs world's first 9c - Project Hard|publisher=UKClimbing|access-date=September 3, 2017}} {{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/adam-ondra-climbing-towards-the-worlds-first-9c.html|title=Interview: Adam Ondra climbing toward the world's first 9C|editor=planetmountain.com|date=June 26, 2017|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{web cite|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Xmx2gYwsYo|title=Adam Ondra: incredible moves in possible 9c|editor=Youtube|date=September 14, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{web cite|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HDlsH3AcHGA|title=Adam Ondra trying the first crux of Project Hard|editor=Youtube|date=September 14, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{web cite|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PVkidzoiJ50#t=2.452307|title=Adam Ondra on the second crux of Project Hard|editor=Youtube|date=September 14, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{web cite|url=https://www.climbing.com/people/adam-ondra-the-future-of-climbing/|title=Adam Ondra: the future of climbing|editor=climbing.com|date=June 7, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{climbing grade|9b+}}: :*''Change'' - [[Flatanger]] ([[Norway|{{ISO 3166 code-3|Norway}}]]) - October 4, 2012 - First ascent by [[Adam Ondra]], who claimed it to be the hardest ascent in history :* ''La Dura Dura'' - [[Oliana]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - February 7, 2013 - First ascent by [[Adam Ondra]]. Route bolted by [[Chris Sharma]], who repeated the ascent one month later and confirmed the grade. :*''Vasil Vasil'' - [[Brno]] ([[Czech Republic|CZE]]) - December 5, 2013{{Cite news|url=https://www.climbing.com/news/ondra-completes-third-5-15c-first-ascent/|title=Ondra Completes Third 5.15c First Ascent|work=Climbing Magazine|access-date=2018-06-22|language=en-us}} - First Ascent by Adam Ondra. His third first ascent of the grade. :*''Perfecto Mundo'' - [[Margalef]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - May 9, 2018 - First ascent by [[Alexander Megos]]. Route bolted by [[Chris Sharma]]. {{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/alexander-megos-frees-perfecto-mundo-9b-plus-at-margalef.html|title=Alexander Megos frees Perfecto Mundo 9b+ at Margalef|editor=planetmountain.com|date=May 9, 2018|access-date=May 9, 2018}} {{climbing grade|9b}}: :* ''Akira'' - Vilhonneur cave ([[Périgord]], [[France|{{ISO 3166 code-3|France}}]]) - June 06, 1995 - First ascent by [[Fred Rouhling]]. He proposed a grade of {{climbing grade|9B}}, but the route is still unrepeated and its grade is not confirmed.{{cite web|url=http://novebi.ning.com/group/eauxclaires/forum/topics/akira-vilhonneur-cave?xg_source=activity|title=Akira, Vilhonneur cave}} :* ''Chilam Balam'' - [[Villanueva del Rosario]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - July 4, 2003 - Unconfirmed{{cite web|url=http://climbingnarc.com/2011/04/adam-ondra-makes-quick-work-of-chilam-balam/|title=Adam Ondra makes quick work of Chilam Balam|publisher=ClimbingNarc}} first ascent claimed by Bernabè Fernandez. He proposed a rating of {{climbing grade|5.15c}}{{cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/andalusiadream/|publisher=Climbing Magazine|title=Andalusia Dreamin'|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310033737/http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/andalusiadream/|archivedate=2011-03-10|df=}} but the route was later repeated by [[Adam Ondra]], who graded it as a "low end" {{climbing grade|5.15b}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?keyid=38067|publisher=Planet Mountain|title=Interview with Adam Ondra after climbing Chilam Balam}} :* ''Jumbo Love'' - [[Clark Mountain (California)|Clark Mountain]] ([[Mojave National Preserve]], [[United States|USA]]) - September 11, 2008 - First ascent by [[Chris Sharma]]. Widely considered the world's first 9b{{By whom?|date=September 2018}}. This route is {{convert|250|ft|m|abbr=on|adj=mid|long}}. Sharma has called it his hardest ascent to date. In climbing it, he skipped up to three clips in a row due to the difficult sequences, which resulted in falls of {{convert|70|ft|m|abbr=on}} or more.{{cite web|url= http://climbingnarc.com/2008/09/chris-sharmas-jumbo-love-515b|title=Chris Sharma’s 'Jumbo Love' (5.15b)|publisher=ClimbingNarc}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bigupproductions.com/#/blog/399/|title=Jumbo Love|publisher=Big Up Productions}}{{cite web |url=http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/sharma_redpoints_clark_mountain_project/ |title=Sharma Redpoints Clark Mountain Project |accessdate=2008-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080914170540/http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/sharma_redpoints_clark_mountain_project/ |archivedate=September 14, 2008 |df= }} Repeated by [[Ethan Pringle]], May 2015.{{cite web|title=Ethan Pringle Repeats Jumbo Love|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/ethan-pringle-repeats-jumbo-love-5-15b/|website=Climbing.com|publisher=Climbing Magazine}}{{cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/andrada515b|title=Andrada Calls New Link-Up 5.15b|publisher=Climbing.com}} [[File:Chris Sharma Climbing in Yangshuo, China.jpg|thumb|250 px|[[Chris Sharma]] climbing in [[Yangshuo]] ([[China|CHI]])]] {{climbing grade|9a+}}: :* ''Open Air'' - [[Schleierfall|Schleier Waterfall]] ([[Austria|AUT]]) - 1996 - First ascent by [[Alexander Huber]], who initially proposed a 9a rating. Heralded as the world's hardest route upon completion, the route was first repeated twelve years later by [[Adam Ondra]], who upgraded it to 9a+, trying to fit the grade to the "new school" rating conventions.{{cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/adam-ondra-open-air-and-hotel-supramonte.html|title=Adam Ondra Open Air and Hotel Supramonte|publisher=Planet Mountain}} According to [[Alexander Huber]],{{cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/alpinism/alexander-huber-interview.html|title=Alexander Huber interview|publisher=Planet Mountain}} the route is at least as difficult as ''[[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla]]'', first climbed by him in 1994. Those who doubt that the original version of ''La Rambla'' is 9a+ (including Huber), might consider ''Open Air'' to be the first 9a+ in history. :* ''[[Realization (climb)|Biographie]]'' - Montagne de [[Céüse]] ([[France|FRA]]) - July 2001 - First ascent by [[Chris Sharma]]. Heralded as world's first 9a+ upon completion, because at that time [[Alexander Huber|Huber]]'s ''Open Air'' was still considered to be a 9a route (see above).{{cite web|url=http://www.camp4.com/news/index.php?newsid=117 |title=Chris Sharma climbs Realization (Biographie extension)! |publisher=Camp4 |date=2006-10-05 |accessdate=2012-01-30}} :* ''[[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla Extension]]'' - [[Siurana (Tarragona)|Siurana]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - {{convert|41|m|ft}} long extended version of [[Alexander Huber]]'s route [[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla]], obtained by Dani Andrada by linking Huber's route to another route nearby, via a traverse - March 8, 2003 - First ascent by [[Ramón Julián Puigblanque]], after more than forty failed attempts. Puigblanque proposed a 9a+ rating, later confirmed by many other repeaters. {{climbing grade|9a}}: :* ''[[Action Directe (climb)|Action Directe]]'' - [[Frankenjura]] ([[Germany|{{ISO 3166 code-3|Germany}}]]) - 1991 - First 9a in history, by [[Wolfgang Gullich]]. Still described as one of the hardest routes worldwide. Originallly graded 8c+, it is now widely considered to be a challenging 9a.{{Cite web|url=http://www.frankenjura.com/klettern/poi/7555|title=Action directe|publisher=frankenjura.com|accessdate=11 June 2013|language=German}} :* ''[[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla]]'' - [[Siurana (Tarragona)|Siurana]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - 1994 - First ascent by [[Alexander Huber]], who graded it {{climbing grade|8c+}}. Based on its similarity with ''[[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla Extension]]'', a {{convert|6|m|ft}} longer version of the same route, La Rambla might be considered to be the world's first 9a+, but Huber would probably disagree. In his opinion, both routes are "not harder than" [[Wolfgang Gullich]]'s ''Action Directe'', the word's first 9a, which in 1994 was still rated 8c+. In 2003, [[Ramón Julián Puigblanque]] climbed both routes and graded them 9a+. Since the additional 6 meters of La Rambla Extension were much easier than La Rambla's [[Crux (climbing)|crux]],{{cite web |url=https://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/hframon/ |title=Statement of Youth (interview with Puigblanque) |accessdate=2017-08-10 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517003058/https://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/hframon/ |archivedate=2008-05-17 |df= }} Puigblanque believed that they did not increase the difficulty of the ascent enough to justify an higher rating. :* ''Bain de Sang'' Saint-Loup ([[Pompaples]], [[Switzerland|SUI]]) - 2012 - First 9a female ascent in history by [[Josune Bereziartu]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/josune-bereziartu-climbs-first-female-9a.html|title=Josune Bereziartu climbs first female 9a}} First ascent by [[Fred Nicole]], 1993. Third 9a route in the world. {{climbing grade|8c+}}: :* ''Hubble'' - Raven Tor ([[United Kingdom|GBR]]) - June 14, 1990 - First 8c+ in history, by [[Ben Moon (rock climber)|Ben Moon]].{{web cite|url=http://desnivel.com/personajes/entrevista-a-ben-moon|title=Entrevista a Ben Moon|editor=desnivel.com|date=June 25, 2001|access-date=January 23, 2012}} Due to failed attempts from some of the world's best climbers, upgrading to 9a was suggested.{{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?l=2&keyid=39015|title=Adam Ondra, the routes I cannot climb!|work=planetmountain.com |year=2015 |accessdate=June 11, 2015}} However, [[Alex Megos]], after repeating it in 2016, stated that this was neither one of his hardest, nor one of his easiest 8c+ routes.{{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/interviews/alexander-megos-climbs-hubble-the-raven-tor-interview.html|title=Alexander Megos climbs Hubble. The Raven Tor interview|date=June 3, 2016|access-date=August 3, 2017}} {{climbing grade|8c}}: :* ''Wallstreet'' - [[Frankenjura]] ([[Germany|DEU]]) - 1987 - First 8c in history, by [[Wolfgang Gullich]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.frankenjura.com/klettern/poi/7618|title=Wallstreet|publisher=frankenjura.com|accessdate=June 11, 2013|language=German}} {{climbing grade|8b+}}: :* ''Ravage'' - [[Basel]] ([[Switzerland|CH]]) - 1985 - First 8b+/c in history, bolted by [[Wenzel Vodicka]] but first ascended by [[Antoine Le Menestrel]].{{cite book |author1=Patrick Andrey|author2=Andreas Luisier|author3=Mike Tscharner |title=Fluebible: Kletterführer Basler Jura : Kletterrouten, Boulderprobleme, Eisfälle |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vOveAQAACAAJ |year=1997 |publisher=Dynamo Productions |isbn=978-3-9521468-0-4}} Repeated in 2009 by [[Adam Ondra]] and in 2017 by [[Alex Megos]].{{web cite|url=https://www.redbull.com/ch-de/helveticlimb-alexander-megos|title=Alex Megos Helveticlimb}} :* ''Punks in the Gym'' - [[Mount Arapiles]] ([[Australia|AUS]]) - 1985 - First 8b+ in history, by [[Wolfgang Gullich]]. {{climbing grade|8b}}: :* ''Kanal im Rücken'' - [[Frankenjura]] ([[Germany|DEU]]) - 1984 - First 8b in history, by [[Wolfgang Gullich]]. [[File:Action Directe 11 (9a), Foto Jorgos Megos.JPG|thumb|250 px|[[Alex Megos]] climbing ''[[Action Directe (climb)|Action Directe]]'' in [[Frankenjura]] ([[Germany|DEU]]), 2014]] === [[Redpoint (climbing)|Redpointed]] by women === {{climbing grade|9b}}: :* ''La Planta de Shiva'' - [[Villanueva del Rosario]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - October 22, 2017 - World's first female ascent of a 9b route, by [[Angela Eiter]].{{cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/interviews/angela-eiter-the-first-woman-to-climb-9b-interview.html|title=Interview with Angela Eiter, the first woman to climb 9b|editor=Planet Mountain|accessdate=24 October 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/angela-eiter-climbs-historic-first-female-9b-with-la-planta-de-shiva-in-spain.html|title=Angela Eiter climbs historic first female 9b|editor=Planet Mountain|accessdate=23 October 2017}} First ascent by [[Adam Ondra]] in 2011. The grade was confirmed by [[Jakob Schubert]] in 2016. {{climbing grade|9a+}}: :* ''[[La Rambla (climb)|La Rambla Extension]]'' - [[Siurana (Tarragona)|Siurana]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - February 26, 2017 - World's first female ascent of a 9a+ route, by [[Margo Hayes]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.up-climbing.com/en/falesia/news/32682|title=Margo Hayes, first female 9a+!!|editor=Up Climbing}}{{cite web|url=http://www.up-climbing.com/en/falesia/news/Margo-Hayes-su-La-Rambla-primo-9a--femminile-al-mondo|title=Margo Hayes on La Rambla, first female 9a+ (video)|editor=Up Climbing}} First ascent by [[Ramon Julian Puigblanque]] in 2003 (see above). The grade was confirmed by many repeaters. {{climbing grade|9a}}: :* ''Bain de Sang'' - Saint Loup ([[Switzerland|SUI]]) - October 29, 2002 - World's first female ascent of a 9a route, by [[Josune Bereziartu]], after 15/20 trials. First ascent by [[Fred Nicole]] in 1993. Third 9a route in the world. The grade was confirmed by many repeaters.{{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/josune-bereziartu-climbs-first-female-9a.html|title=Josune Bereziartu climbs first female 9a (interview)|editor=Planet Mountain}} === [[Onsight]]ed === {{climbing grade|9A}}: :* ''Estado Critico'' - Siurana ([[Spain|ESP]]) - 24 March 2013 - First 9a onsight in history by [[Alex Megos]]. :* ''Cabane au Canada'' - Rawyl ([[Switzerland|SUI]]) - 9 July 2013 - by [[Adam Ondra]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.ukclimbing.com/news/item.php?id=68197|title=La cabane au Canada, 9a, onsight by Ondra|publisher=ukclimbing.com|author=Björn Pohl|date=9 July 2013|accessdate=10 July 2013}} :* ''Il Domani'' - Baltzola ([[Spain|ESP]]) - 3 May 2014 - by [[Adam Ondra]]. {{climbing grade|8C+}}: :* ''Bizi Euskaraz'' - [[Etxauri]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - December 11, 2007 - First 8c+ onsight in history by [[Patxi Usobiaga]]. Project by Ekaitz Maiz.{{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/News/shownews1.lasso?l=1&keyid=35934|title=Patxi Usobiaga show: Bizi euskaraz primo 8c+ a vista del mondo|editor=planetmountain.com|date=December 13, 2007|access-date=January 8, 2012}} :* ''Kidetasunaren balio erantsia'' - [[Etxauri]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - 6 March 2011 - Second 8c+ onsight in history, by Adam Ondra.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kairn.com/news_escalade_74602.adam-ondra-deuxieme-homme-reussir-8c-vue.html|title=Adam Ondra, deuxième homme à réussir du 8c+ à vue (édité)|work=Kairn.com|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=7 October 2012|language=fr}}[http://desnivel.com/escalada-roca/adam-ondra-8c-mas--a-vista-en-etxauri Adam Ondra, 8c+ on-sight at Etxauri] {{climbing grade|8C}}: :* ''White Zombi'', Baltzola Cave ([[Spain|ESP]]) - October 6, 2004 - World's first 8c onsight, by Yuji Hirayama.{{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/hirayama-worlds-first-8c-on-sight.html|title=Yuji Hirayama world's first 8c on-sight!}} === [[Free solo climbing|Free-solo]] climbed === There are few climbers who have free-soled in the [[Grade_(climbing)|5.14 grade]] range. This list does not include "highball" boulder ascents because the climbers here did not use any padding or spotters. There is some debate on the blurred line between "highball" [[bouldering]] and short free solo climbs.{{web cite|url=http://www.allclimbing.com/archive/2009/01/kevin-jorgeson-sends-ambrosia-and-blurs-line-between-highball-and-free-solo/|title=Kevin Jorgeson sends Ambrosia and blurs line between highball and free solo}} {{climbing grade|8C}}: :* ''Darwin Dixit'' - Length: {{convert|15|m|ft|}} - [[Margalef]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - March 2008 - The first 8c free solo, by [[Dave MacLeod]].{{web cite|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/macleod-solos-514b-in-spain/|title=MacLeod solos 5.14b in Spain}} {{climbing grade|8B+}}: :* ''Kommunist'' - Length: {{convert|22|m|ft|}} - [[Tyrol]] ([[Austria|AUT]]) - 2004 - The first 8b+ free solo, by [[Alexander Huber]].{{web cite|url=http://www.alpinist.com/doc/web08x/wfeature-solo-huber|title=Huber solos 5.14a in Austria}} === Hardest projects=== [[Chris Sharma]] is currently working on an extremely ambitious project that in his opinion may turn out to be harder than {{climbing grade|9b+}}: :* ''Le blond'' - [[Oliana]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - Project by Chris Sharma, immediately to the right of ''La Dura Dura'' (world's first confirmed 9b+). {{web cite|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YwODjN5sKLI&vl=es|title=Chris Sharma, The Blonde, 9C|editor=Youtube|date=September 8, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} {{web cite|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/chris-sharma-in-le-blond-project-at-oliana.html|title=Chris Sharma in Le Blond project at Oliana|editor=planetmountain.com|date=August 26, 2016|access-date=August 1, 2017}} Named after [[Patrick Edlinger]], who passed away while Sharma was bolting the route. [[File:Es pontas 2.jpg|thumbnail|[[Es Pontàs]], a natural arch in the coast of [[Mallorca]]]] == [[Deep-water solo]] routes == {{Climbing grade|9b}} (unconfirmed): :* ''Alasha'' - [[Mallorca]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - September 12, 2016. First ascent by [[Chris Sharma]], who estimated its grade based on the effort it took to climb it without rope: "If it had bolts on it, it probably wouldn’t be a 9b (5.15b). But when you’re 60 feet up with no bolts, it takes the same amount of effort.” {{cite web|url=http://www.rockandice.com/climbing-news/chris-sharma-sends-Alasha-5-15-deep-water-solo-project|title=Chris Sharma Sends Five-Year 5.15 Deep Water Solo Project|publisher=Rock and Ice|date=September 29, 2016|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} Sharma named the route after his daughter, Alana Sharma. {{Climbing grade|9a+}}: :* ''[[Es Pontàs]]'' - [[Mallorca]] ([[Spain|ESP]]) - September 26, 2007. First ascent by [[Chris Sharma]]. Repeated by Jernej Kruder in November 2016. It features a {{convert|7|ft|m}} dyno that took Sharma over 50 attempts to stick. {{cite web|url=http://www.freakclimbing.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=1364 |title=Chris Sharma sends his mega Arch Project in Mallorca - News |publisher=FreakClimbing.com |date=2006-09-28 |accessdate=2012-01-30}} {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yOQYlheOLy4||title=Reel Rock: King Lines, Part 2|publisher=Youtube|date=September 9, 2014|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} [[File:Organ Pipes, Mt Wellington - Battlements, Bryan Kennedy.jpg|thumb|[[Bryan Kennedy (climber)|Bryan Kennedy]] free soloing the ''Kennedy variant'' to the Organ Pipes, [[Mount Wellington (Tasmania)|Mount Wellington]] ([[Australia|AUS]]), 1977]] == Multi-[[pitch (climbing)|pitch]] routes == === [[Redpoint (climbing)|Redpointed]] === {{climbing grade|9A}}: :* ''The Dawn Wall'' - [[El Capitan]] ([[Yosemite]], [[United States|USA]]) - Height: 3,000 feet (915 meters) - 32 pitches, at least two of which graded {{climbing grade|9A}}. Described as the hardest big wall in the world. ::: January 14, 2015 - Redpointed by [[Tommy Caldwell]] and [[Kevin Jorgeson]] in 19 days, after 7 years of practicing.{{cite web|last=Bello|first=Marisol|date=January 15, 2015|title=Yosemite free-climbers reach top of El Capitan|publisher=usatoday.com|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/01/14/yosemite-free-climbers/21737187/}}{{cite web |last=Bisharat|first=Andrew|date=January 15, 2015|title=Summiting Yosemite's Dawn Wall, Climbers Make History|website=news.nationalgeographic.com|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2015/01/150114-climbing-yosemite-caldwell-jorgeson-capitan/|accessdate=2015-01-15}} ::: November 21, 2016 - Redpointed by [[Adam Ondra]] in only 8 days, after a few weeks of practicing.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/11/23/czech-free-climber-adam-ondra-scales-yosemite-rock-wall-record/ Czech free-climber Adam Ondra scales Yosemite rock wall in record time] ([[The Daily Telegraph]]) Ondra was the first person to [[Lead climbing|lead]] every pitch.{{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/adam-ondra-completes-dawn-wall/|title=Adam Ondra Completes Dawn Wall|work=Climbing|accessdate=22 November 2016}} {{climbing grade|8b}}: :* The Nose - [[El Capitan]] ([[Yosemite]], [[United States|USA]]) - Height: 3,000 feet (915 meters) - 31 pitches one of which is graded at 5.14a/b. Described as one of the most important ascents in climbing history.{{Cite journal|last=Caldwell|first=Tommy|date=2008|title=Mountain Profile: The Captain|url=|journal=Alpinist|volume=25|pages=46-47|via=}}{{Cite news|url=|title=Climb Like a Girl|last=Hightower|first=Elizabeth|date=4 March 2007|work=New York Times|access-date=}} 1993 − First to free climb, [[Lynn Hill]] with partner Brooke Sandahl. Was not repeated for 10 years after their ascent. === [[Free solo climbing|Free-solo]] climbed === {{climbing grade|7c+}}: :* ''Freerider'': [[El Capitan]] ([[Yosemite]], [[United States|USA]]) - Height: 3,000 feet (915 meters) - June 3, 2017 - First free solo ascent on El Capitan, and world's hardest multi-pitch free solo by [[Alex Honnold]]. Time: 3 hours, 56 minutes{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/features/athletes/alex-honnold/most-dangerous-free-solo-climb-yosemite-national-park-el-capitan/|title=Exclusive: Climber Completes the Most Dangerous Rope-Free Ascent Ever|date=3 June 2017|publisher=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/06/us/california-today-alex-honnold-el-capitan-climb.html|title=California Today: An ‘Incomprehensible’ Climb in Yosemite|last=Mcphate|first=Mike|date=2017-06-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-06-06|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}{{web cite|url=https://www.climbing.com/videos/the-first-video-of-alex-honnolds-freerider-free-solo/|title=Video of Alex Honnold's Freerider}} [[File:Christian Core on Gioia.jpg|thumb|[[Christian Core]] on ''Gioia'' ([[Varazze]], [[Italy|ITA]]), first {{Boulder grade|8C+}} boulder in history, 2008]] [[File:Midnight Lightning yosemite.jpg|thumb|Michael Rael Armas on ''Midnight Lightning'', [[Camp 4 (Yosemite)|Camp 4]] ([[Yosemite National Park]], [[United States|USA]]), one of the world's most famous bouldering problems]] == [[Bouldering|Boulder problems]] == {{Boulder grade|9A}} (unconfirmed): :*''Burden of Dreams'' - Lappnor ([[Finland|{{ISO 3166 code-3|Finland}}]]) - October 2016 - Grade proposed by [[Nalle Hukkataival]] after several years of trials. During these years, Hukkataival "very quickly" solved several 8C and 8C+ boulder problems throughout the world, including ''Gioia'' (see below). Compared to these other problems, ''Burden of Dreams'' felt "way way harder".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4DQf7aGO1uU|title=Interview: Nalle Hukkataival - Burden of Dreams (9A bloc)|publisher=Relais Vertical|accessdate=2 September 2017}} {{Boulder grade|8C+}}: :* ''Gioia'' - Varezze ([[Italy|ITA]]) - 2008 - First ascent by Italian boulderer [[Christian Core]], who first proposed 8C, "to play things safe". In 2011, [[Adam Ondra]] repeated the ascent and wholeheartedly proposed the 8C+ grade, describing the boulder as one of the hardest in the world, together with ''Terranova'' (see below).{{cite web |url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/adam-ondra-the-pure-gioia-interview.html|title=Adam Ondra, the pure Gioia interview|publisher=Planetmountain|date=7 December 2011 |accessdate=1 August 2017}} :* ''Terranova'' - [[Holstejn]] ([[Moravsky Kras]], [[Czech Republic|CZE]]) - 10 November 2011 - First ascent by [[Adam Ondra]].{{cite web |url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/adam-ondra-frees-terranova-8c-.html|title=Adam ondra frees Terranova 8C+|date=15 November 2011 |accessdate=1 August 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ukclimbing.com/news/item.php?id=64987|title=8C+ boulder by Ondra|work=UKClimbing.com|author=Björn Pohl|accessdate=7 October 2012}} {{Boulder grade|8C}}: :* ''The story of two worlds'' - [[Cresciano]] ([[Switzerland|SUI]]) - January 2005 - First confirmed 8C in history, by [[Dave Graham (climber)|Dave Graham]]. {{cite news |url=http://www.freakclimbing.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=389|title=Dave Graham, 'The story of two worlds' his new 8C and his new grading philosophy|publisher=FreakClimbing|date=19 January 2005|accessdate=1 August 2017}} Five years earlier, [[Fred Nicole]] had proposed 8C for ''Dreamtime'', on the other side of the same boulder, but most repeaters downgraded it to 8b+ (see below). :* ''The Game'' - [[Boulder, Colorado]] ([[United States|USA]]) - 2010 - First ascent by [[Daniel Woods]], who originally graded it {{Boulder grade|8C+}}.{{cite news |url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?l=2&keyid=37243 |title=Daniel Woods plays The Game Fb8C+ |publisher=PlanetMountain |date=12 February 2010 |accessdate=11 August 2013}} Second ascent in 2013 by Carlo Traversi, who proposed {{Boulder grade|8C}}.{{cite news |url=http://climbingnarc.com/2011/03/carlo-traversi-repeats-the-game-v15-in-boulder-canyon/|title=Carlo Traversi repeats The Game (V15) in boulder canyon|publisher=Climbing Narc|date= March 12, 2011||accessdate=1 August 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.dpmclimbing.com/articles/view/carlo-traversi-sends-game-v1516 |title=Carlo Traversi Sends The Game (V15/16) |publisher=DPM Climbing |date=12 March 2011 |accessdate=11 August 2013}} :* ''Lucid Dreaming'' - [[Bishop, California]] ([[United States|USA]]) - 2010 - First ascent by [[Paul Robinson (climber)|Paul Robinson]], who initially graded it {{Boulder grade|8C+}},{{cite news |url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?l=2&keyid=37330 |title=Lucid Dreaming, new extreme boulder problem at the Buttermilks, Bishop |publisher=PlanetMountain |date=31 March 2010 |accessdate=11 August 2013}} and later downgraded it. In 2010, together with ''The game'' (see above), this was considered to be one of the world's most challenging boulders. Second ascent by [[Daniel Woods]], who confirmed the {{Boulder grade|8C}} grade.{{cite web |url=http://climbingnarc.com/2014/01/daniel-woods-does-repeat-lucid-dreaming/ |title=Daniel Woods Does Repeat Lucid Dreaming |publisher=Climbing Narcissist |date=28 January 2014 |accessdate=30 January 2014}} {{Boulder grade|8b+}}: :* ''Dreamtime'' - [[Cresciano]] ([[Switzerland|SUI]]) - October 28, 2000 - First ascent by [[Fred Nicole]], who proposed an 8C rating, making it the first unconfirmed 8C boulder in history. In 2002, [[Dave Graham (climber)|Dave Graham]] repeated it by finding a different solution. He used a [[Glossary of climbing terms#heel hook|heel-hook]] to make the brutal start sequence easier, and downgraded the problem to easy 8b+. Most of the following repeaters, including [[Adam Ondra]], [[Chris Sharma]], and [[Daniel Woods]] adopted Graham's solution and agreed with him about the grade.{{cite web |url=https://www.99boulders.com/hardest-boulder-problems|title=Hardest boulder problems|publisher=99boulders|date=October 26, 2016|accessdate=August 1, 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://community.mammut.ch/t5/Mammut-Magazine/The-Classics-Dreamtime/ba-p/2875|title=The classics - Dreamtime|publisher=Mammut Magazine|date=July 5, 2017|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} Notable exceptions are [[Jan Hojer]] and [[Christian Core]], who confirmed the 8C rating.[https://www.8a.nu/?IncPage=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.8a.nu%2Fuser%2FProfile.aspx%3FUserId%3D16898 Hojer Comments about Dreamtime on 8a.nu] {{Boulder grade|7B+}}: :* ''[[Midnight Lightning (bouldering)|Midnight Lightning]]'' - [[Camp 4 (Yosemite)|Camp 4]] ([[Yosemite National Park]], [[United States|USA]]) - 1978 - First ascent by [[Ron Kauk]]. First female ascent by [[Lynn Hill]], 1998. {{Cite web |url=http://adventure.nationalgeographic.com/2008/09/yosemite/climbing-photosynth-text |title=Yosemite in 3-D |author=Corey Rich |date=August 2008 |accessdate=9 May 2013 |publisher=National Geographic}} {{Cite web |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1064893/5/index.htm |title=On The Rocks, Kauk Is It |author=Sam Moses |publisher=Sport Illustrated |date=2 June 1986 |accessdate=9 May 2013}} {{Cite web |url=https://www.mountainproject.com/v/midnight-lightning/105835104 |title=Midnight Lightning - Mountain Project}} Thirtynine years after its solution, it has been described as one of the world's most famous bouldering problems, together with ''Dreamtime'' (see above). {{Cite web |url=http://www.planetmountain.com/english/News/shownews1.lasso?l=2&keyid=40853 |title=Midnight Lightning bolt, the icon of free climbing in Yosemite disappears for a day |publisher=planetmountain.com |date=7 May 2013 |accessdate=9 May 2013}} == See also == *[[History of rock climbing]] *[[List of first ascents]] *[[List of highest mountains on Earth#List|List of first ascents on the highest mountains on Earth]] *[[Exploration of the High Alps]] *[[List of first ascents in the Sierra Nevada (U.S.)]] *[[List of first ascents in the Cordillera Blanca]] == References == {{Reflist|refs= {{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/ondra-puts-down-la-dura-dura-5-15c/|title=Ondra Puts Down La Dura Dura (5.15c)|work=Climbing|accessdate=7 February 2013}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/news/ondra-5-15c-norway/|title=Adam Ondra Climbs 5.15c in Norway|work=Climbing|author=Dougald MacDonald|date=4 October 2012|accessdate=7 October 2012}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/it/notizie/interviste/alexander-megos-lintervista-dopo-il-primo-9a-a-vista-mondiale.html|title=First 9A onsight by Alex Mesgos}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/en/news/climbing/nalle-hukkataival-climbs-burden-of-dreams-and-proposes-worlds-first-9a-boulder-problem.html|title=Nalle Hukkataival climbs Burden of Dreams and proposes world's first 9a boulder problem|editor=Planet Mountain}} }} == External links == * {{Cite web|url=http://www.planetmountain.com/it/notizie/arrampicata/levoluzione-dellarrampicata-libera.html|title=The evolution of free climbing|language=Italian|publisher=Planet Mountain|author=Maurizio Oviglia|date=December 21, 2012}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.99boulders.com/hardest-boulder-problems|title=Hardest boulder problems|publisher=99boulders|date=October 26, 2016|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} [[Category:Sport climbing]] [[Category:Rock climbing|02]] [[Category:History of sports|Rock]] [[Category:Climbing and mountaineering-related lists]]

revision.text:
<!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to running:
'''[[Running]]''' – means of rapidly traveling on foot, in which at regular points during the running cycle both feet are off the ground. Running is a key component to a number of sporting events typically in the realm of road racing, track and field or triathlon.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== Nature of running ==
Running can be described as:
* [[Physical exercise|Exercise]] ** [[Aerobic exercise]] * A sport ** A component of [[athletics (sport)|athletics]] ** An [[individual sport]] ** A [[team sport]] (see [[relay race]]) * A form of [[travel]] ** [[Animal locomotion]] *** [[Terrestrial locomotion]]
== Forms of running == [[Image:MNSTATE.jpg|thumb|250px|The Minnesota state high school cross country meet, with [[Elliott Heath]] and [[Hassan Mead]] leading.]]
*[[Backward running]] * [[Barefoot running]] * [[Sprint (running)|Sprint]]ing * [[Jogging]] * [[ChiRunning]] * [[Level and Incline Running]] * [[Long-distance running]] – form of continuous running over distances of at least five kilometres (3.1 miles). Physiologically, it is largely aerobic in nature and requires stamina as well as mental strength.
=== Running sports events === * [[Track and field]] ** [[Sprint (running)|Sprints]] ***[[50 metres|50 m]] ***[[55 metres|55 m]] ***[[60 metres|60 m]] *** [[100 metres|100 m]] ***[[150 metres|150 m]] *** [[200 metres|200 m]] *** [[300 metres|300 m]] *** [[400 metres|400 m]] ***[[500 metres|500 m]] **[[Hurdling|Hurdles]] ***[[50 metres hurdles|50 m]] ***[[55 metres hurdles|55 m]] ***[[60 metres hurdles|60 m]] ***[[100 metres hurdles|100 m]] ***[[110 metres hurdles|110 m]] ***[[400 metres hurdles|400 m]] ** [[Middle distance running]] *** [[800 metres|800 m]] ***[[1500 metres|1500 m]] *** [[3000 metres|3000 m]] ***[[Steeplechase (athletics)|Steeplechase]] ** [[Long-distance track event]]s ***[[5000 metres|5000 m]] ***[[10,000 metres|10,000 m]] ***[[One hour run]] ** [[Relay race|Relays]] *** [[4 × 100 metres relay|4 × 100 m]] *** [[4 × 200 metres relay|4 × 200 m]] *** [[4 × 400 metres relay|4 × 400 m]] ***[[4 × 800 metres relay|4 × 800 m]] ***[[Distance medley relay]] *** [[Sprint medley relay]] *** [[Swedish relay]] * [[Road running]] **[[5 kilometres (road running)|5K]] ***[[:Category:5K runs|5K race profiles]] **[[10 kilometres (road running)|10K]] ***[[:Category:10K runs|10K race profiles]] **[[Quarter marathon]] **[[10-miles (road running)|10-miles]] ***[[:Category:10-mile races|10 mile race profiles]] **[[20 kilometres (road running)|20K]] **[[Half marathon]] ***[[:Category:Half marathons|Specific half marathon profiles]] **[[Marathon]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in Argentina|Specific Argentina marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in Australia|Specific Australian marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in Canada|Specific Canadian marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in China|Specific Chinese marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in Europe|Specific European marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in Germany|Specific German marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in India|Specific Indian marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in Japan|Specific Japan marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in Lithuania|Specific Lithuanian marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in Pakistan|Specific Pakistani marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in Slovenia|Specific Slovenian marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in the United Kingdom|Specific U.K. marathon profiles]] ***[[:Category:Marathons in the United States|Specific U.S. Marathon profiles]] **[[Ultramarathon]] ** [[Multiday race]] ** [[Ekiden]] * Off-road running * [[Adventure running]] *[[Cross country running]] **[[Fell running]] ***[[:Category:Fell running competitions|Fell running competitions]] **[[Mountain running]] ***[[:Category:Mountain running competitions|Mountain running events]] * [[Trail running]] * Multi-discipline sports of which running is a part: ** [[Multisport race|Multisports]] that include running: *** [[Adventure racing]] *** [[Aquathlon]] *** [[Duathlon]] *** [[Triathlon]] – which includes running as its final, third component *** [[Quadrathlon]] ** [[Tetrathlon]] ** [[Modern pentathlon]] ** [[Heptathlon]] ** [[Octathlon]] ** [[Decathlon]] * [[Tower running]]
== Running venues == *[[List of largest running events]]
== Running equipment == * [[Footwear]] **[[Athletic shoe]] **[[Racing flats]] ** [[Sock]]s **[[Track spikes]] * [[Cheetah Flex-Foot]] * [[Running shorts]] * [[Transponder timing|Timing transponder]]
== Injury prevention == * [[Stretching]] * [[Cross-training]]
== Physiology of running == * [[Running#Motion|Gait]]
=== Running injuries === * [[Achilles tendon]] ** [[Achilles tendinitis]] ** [[Achilles tendon rupture]] * [[Blister|Foot blisters]] * [[Iliotibial band syndrome]] * [[Pulled muscle]] ** [[Pulled hamstring]] * [[Runner's knee]] * [[Runner's toe]] * [[Shin splints]] * [[Sprained ankle]] * [[Stress fracture]]s
== History of running ==
History of running * [[Persistence hunting]] * [[Running in Ancient Greece]] ** [[Stadion (running race)]] ** [[Dolichos (running race)]] ** [[Diaulos (running race)]] * [[Marathon#History|History of the marathon]] * [[Four-minute mile]]
==Running organizations== *[[Amateur Athletic Association]] – the oldest national governing body for athletics in the world, having been established on 24 April 1880. *[[Athletics Canada]] *[[Athletics New Zealand]] *[[International Association of Athletics Federations]] (IAAF) **[[Asian Athletics Association]] – sponsor of the [[Asian Championships in Athletics|Asian Championships]] **[[Confederation of African Athletics]] – sponsor of the [[African Championships in Athletics]] **[[CONSUDATLE]] – sponsor of the [[South American Championships in Athletics]] and the [[South American Cross Country Championships]] **[[European Athletic Association]] – sponsor of the [[European Championships]] **[[North America, Central America and Caribbean Athletic Association]] (NACAC) sponsor of the [[NACAC Championships]] **[[Oceania Athletics Association]] – sponsor of the [[Oceania Athletics Championships]] *[[Road Runners Club of America]] *[[UK Athletics]] *[[USA Track & Field]]
== Persons influential in running == [[Image:Osaka07 D1M M100M Heat Astafa Powell.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Previous world record holder [[Asafa Powell]] leading a race.]]
===Great Britain=== * [[Roger Bannister]] – first person to run the mile in less than 4 minutes. *[[David Cecil, 6th Marquess of Exeter]] (1905–1981) – president of the IAAF for 30 years *[[Sebastian Coe]] – retired Olympian who heads London's bid for the [[2012 Summer Olympics]]; held all four middle distance world records simultaneously, the 800 m, 1000 m, 1500 m and the mile. *[[Mo Farah]] CBE - Britain's most successful distance runner.
===France=== *[[Pierre de Coubertin]] (1863–1937) – founder of the modern [[Olympics]]
===Morocco=== *[[Hicham El Guerrouj]] – current holder of the 1500 metres, mile and outdoor 2000 metres world records, as well as a double Olympic gold medalist. Ran the mile in 3:43.13 in Rome in 1999.
===New Zealand=== *[[Arthur Lydiard]] (1917–2004), runner and coach.
===Senegal=== *[[Lamine Diack]], president of the IAAF since November 1999
===United States=== *[[Avery Brundage]] (1887–1975) – long-time president of the [[International Olympic Committee]] *[[Ollan Cassell]] – long-time head of the [[USA Track & Field]] *[[Ted Corbitt]] (1919–2007) – founder of the Road Runners Club of America and founding president of New York Road Runners. He led efforts to accurately measure and certify long distance road race courses in the United States. *[[Jim Fixx]] – author of the 1977 best-selling book, ''[[The Complete Book of Running]]''. He helped start America's fitness revolution, popularizing the sport of running and demonstrating the health benefits of regular jogging. *[[Don Kardong]] – past-president of the [[Road Runners Club of America]] *[[Fred Lebow]] (1932–1994) – long-time head of the NY Road Runners and creator of the "big city" marathon format *[[Bill Rodgers (athlete)|Bill Rodgers]] – influential runner as both an open and master runner *[[Steve Prefontaine|Steve Roland "Pre" Prefontaine]] (January 25, 1951 – May 30, 1975) 1971 Olympiad, lifetime runner, 1970s running icon, auto-accident death.
== See also == *[[Eco-running]] *[[ChiRunning]] *[[Ernst van Aaken]] *[[Orienteering]] * [[Racewalking]] **[[20 kilometres race walk|20 km walk]] * [[Wheelchair racing]] {{Clear}}
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == {{Sisterlinks|Running}}
* {{dmoz|Sports/Running/}} * {{Cite EB1911|wstitle=running|volume=23|pages=853–854}}
{{Outline footer}}
